content:
While the puzzle is nice, I'm currently working on it, this ends up being much more of a math problem that anything else. Especially with the gradient descent, computation of derivatives and errors squarings. If you're not familiar with those concepts, good luck.
As a result I'd say the programming side of the puzzle is between easy and medium, but the mathematical background required to actually solve it pushes it way higher on the ladder.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very neat problem, although I feel like I got tricked into doing someone's thesis :) ...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very original contribution, and nice ASCII arts!
Nice one.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's an interesting puzzle, with a lot of effort done.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
super jeu j'adore les combats de bots
seems nice
good idea
Input, change "Next lines" to "Next [[h]] lines"
You have a number of references in your solution, perhaps some of those could be useful in a References: section of your problem statement?
Consider supplying a 0 before the decimal point for electron, and whether other decimal places will be supplied for other particles.

Change "ration g =" to "ratio g ="; consider if you mean circle or arc.
Also, since q and m are supplied, the programmer can easily compute g, so it needn't be supplied.
Consider changing "allows to detects microscopic particles as" to "allows scientists to detect charged particles such as"
Very nice physics problem !
Nice ASCII-art :D
I like it very much. Captivating problem!
For the first test & validator, if the magnetic field is zero, you can't know if the particle is neutral. Or I don't understand something (my physical knowlegde are old)

It's an interesting puzzle, but Statement is incomplete or I've read it bad:

A)
Lorentz factor is y(V) = 1/Sqrt(1-V*V)
I don't see the inverse in your statement.

B)
You define a gap_threshold of 0.5 to determine if a particle is known or not. That's not stated in the description, so I wasn't detecting any unknown because I just went to the near particle.

C)
I'm not a fan of getting rounded values, especially on pixelated circles. Calculated ratio might not be exactly the same with different approaches.

D)
 your solution did a 
"round_R_recompute = int(round(R_recompute / 10.) * 10)" that is not stated anywhere. 

I'm passing all validators and tests except Test 6, I'm getting a different radius. Probably of how I calculate a radius from an arc. 
https://pastebin.com/csrQpEmG
It's a fast code, probably broken/wrong, but you can see the Test 6 radius error.
very nice :)
Thank you very much Quả cà chua nhỏ ;-)

Thank you for those insteresting remarks.

A. Indeed, I made a typo in Lorentz factor formula.

B. I added the gap_thresold = .5 at the end of my dev, and I forgot to describe this in the statement. You are right, players does not have to guess when decide a particle is known/unknown, I will add an instruction.

C. I am not sure of what you mean. Is about float value of |q|/m ratio? or about rounding radius to the closest tenth?

D. Same as B, it was a lately dev! I will add an instruction.
About
round_R_recompute = int(round(R_recompute / 10.) * 10)
it is the only way I found to check the radius within an incertainty range. Check if recompute radius belongs to R_exact ± 10% would be better, but I don’t see any way to do it within test/validator as they can only check if two strings are equal.

I will have a look to your code, I don’t know C# (but a little bit of C), it will be a nice first experience :-) !
Test 6 is one of the hardest, because the radius is quite big in relation to the size of the image, so the arc is close to a straigth line. So if one test may fail, it will probably be the 6th!

Exact!
And I wrote it at the beginning of the statement :facepalm: !
Actually, I put B=0 for test/validator 1 because magnetic field strength does not change the path of the neutron, so any value would be well suited... any values except those too close to zero.
Thank you very much! Cloud chamber are amazing :-)

Your comment make me wonder if only charged particle could be detected by cloud chamber, as surprising as it would be, I did not think about it before!

According to
http://www.ep.ph.bham.ac.uk/twiki/bin/view/General/CloudChamber
cloud chamber detect ionizing particle, that include charged particle but not only, e.g. photon are cited as exemple.
Neutrons are ionizing radiation:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutron_radiation
so as such, there are detectable by a cloud chamber, as photon:
https://www.quora.com/Are-neutrons-invisible-to-cloud-chambers-How-about-alpha-beta-and-gamma-particles

But, neutron and photon does not directly make a wake on their path as charged particle: they produce indirect effect through collisions with particles of the atmosphere of the cloud chamber.

So you make a point! Neutrons does not make a straigh wake.
So, maybe I should remove neutron from particle list and from test/validators…
By the way, straight lines are not the most interessing part of the algorithm, it would not be a great lost to discart them.
What do you think :-)?
Done :-)
Done :-)
Done :-)
Done :-)

Thank you very much :-) !
By the way, I feel ashamed that I still not look further at your C# solution.
I saw that you use a clever and far simple method (based on some geometric properties, I did not know which one yet!) to retrieve the radius (tell me if I’m wrong!)
But I fear that’s the reason it fails on the test #6 which is the hardest, since you only use extreme and middle point, it fails when arc are too narrow (angularely).
To be continued...
Simple hill climbing with 10000 iterations does the job :-)
Thank you very much :-)

Thank you very much :-)
Indeed, I get inspiration from some part of my thesis, well seen :-D !

I agree about the volume of maths, but only if you use gradient descent as I did.
Actually, many people (including my wife, *Marchete* and *CarlWalsh*) took a very much simpler road by computing the circlus radius with three points.
Advantage of gradient descent is the precision (if you iterate enough), but as the radius is rounded to the closest multiple of 10 (I did this to decrease the difficulty), here, gradient descent is like killing a fly with a flame-thrower!
The 3-points magic trick:
https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/213658/get-the-equation-of-a-circle-when-given-3-points/213678#213678

Actually, when my wife and a few other people solved my puzzle with a so simple geometric trick, I was almost disapointed that my puzzle could be solved with a so much simpler algorithm than mine! But finally, that’s cool, simplicity is elegant :-)

Oh :-o ! I did not know this algorithm.
I am curious about how you make it... but maybe it is top secret :-D !

Don't read it, it was just some fast code to test the basics, and it served well for that purpose. It's a matter of searching a better approach, rounding radius to the tenth is OK.

 I think the description is complete enough to publish it.
Roger :-) !
Keep the neutrons, change to say statement to say "allows scientists to visualize the passage of ionizing radiation such as"
Done :-)
